description.plain:
William Roberts II, known under his stage name Rick Ross (Sometimes stylized as Rick Ro$$), has rapidly ascended the hip-hop ranks. He started his career writing for and making occasional appearances on records on the Slip-n-Slide label.  As soon as he got a chance for a solo album, he never looked back, launching popular album one after the other he built one of the most successful rap careers of the 2000s.  Ross is known for his booming baritone voice, luscious beard, and signature grunt.

His 2006 platinum debut album Port of Miami contained the debut smash record “Hustlin'” and got to #1 on the Billboard charts. Since then, Ross has continued to release top-selling albums.

Ross is also the founder of the highly successful Maybach Music Group label which has powerhouse artists Meek Mill and Wale signed to it, among others. The label has seen nine solo and three compilation albums, including five certified Gold albums.

songs.title: Stay Schemin’

description.plain:
“Stay Schemin’” is a single from Rick Ross' second mixtape Rich Forever featuring Drake and French Montana.

The track was released as a digital download from iTunes on April 17, 2012. The chorus of the song interpolates an unreleased Nas song, “Day Dreamin, Stay Schemin”. The unreleased song is a cover of Kurtis Blow’s song, “Daydreamin'”.

songs.full_title: Diced Pineapples by Rick Ross (Ft. Drake & Wale)
songs.title: Diced Pineapples

description.plain:
Perhaps the greatest title for a song ever, featuring MMG cohort Wale and OVO’s Drake. The song is produced by Cardiak.

Ross stated the concept of the song:

“When I got out of the hospital — you know, I had a seizure last year — when I was leaving, the doctor told me, ‘You gotta eat some more fruit, drink you some water, eat fruit and just relax for a little while.’ My fruit of choice was pineapples. For the next three weeks, I woke up every morning and ate diced pineapples, and I put the concept together. Drizzy came in, as well as Wale, and it’s kinda like, ‘She could be my diced pineapple. This special lady, she could be what I wake up to every morning and help me get by every day.”

description.plain:
The mood of this song, as Ross stated, is that music you play in your two-seater with your favorite female (of the week) just riding together feeling like BAWSES.

Producer Rook of J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League talked about the track:


Man, the hardest part about making that beat was creating a sound. But even then, you just go through a trance and start experimenting. I think the main inspiration for that was Prince and old-school R&B like Cherrelle and The Whispers. Even Ice Cube ‘You Know How We Do It’ and ‘It Was a Good Day.’ Like, as soon as the song comes on, you know exactly what the fuck it is.

We didn’t do the song specifically for Ross. A few other people made songs to it. Actually, I sent it to Drake before I sent it to Ross. Ross did the song with him and Chrisette Michele, and DJ Khaled sent it to Drake. Then when Drake got it, he text me and was like, ‘Yo! Why didn’t you send me this beat?!’ I was like, ‘My man, that was in the first set of beats I sent you’ [laughs]. He got on it and did his thing, though.


While Drake initially provided the chorus, a remix version with a Drake verse was later released and had a music video. The single topped Billboard’s Hot Rap Songs chart for 18 weeks. The song was officially re-released as Paris Morton Music in 2019.

songs.full_title: Gold Roses by Rick Ross (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Gold Roses

description.plain:
“Gold Roses” serves as the lead single off of Rick Ross’s 10th studio album, Port of Miami 2.

Frequent collaborators Drake and Ross go back and forth over a slow, thumping beat, rapping about where life stands at this moment in time.

This track comes a month after the duo collaborated on Drake’s “Money in the Grave.”

songs.full_title: Idols Become Rivals by Rick Ross (Ft. Chris Rock)
songs.title: Idols Become Rivals

description.plain:
“Idols Become Rivals” is a diss track directed at Rick Ross' idol-turned-rival, Birdman. Ross had a falling out with Birdman and lost respect for him after his treatment of Lil Wayne; namely his financial misdeeds and efforts to prevent the release of Tha Carter V. In a December 2015 interview with The Breakfast Club, Ross said:

Right now, really me just seeing what Wayne going through as an artist, me idolizing Birdman at a time, me looking up to Lil Wayne, Wayne being the first artist making to make so many feats not just as an artist but an artist coming through the South, that’s something I took personal. For me to see the way things are transpiring, I can’t respect that, and I don’t respect that.

The song’s title is inspired by a 2010 Drake lyric from “Thank Me Now,” where he says:

And that’s around the time
That your idols become your rivals
You make friends with Mike
But got to A.I. him for your survival

The track samples Camilo Sesto’s 1978 track “Agua De Dos Rios,” the same song Jay Z used as the basis for his 2000 song “Where Have You Been.” Coincidentally, Jay’s track finds him and Beanie Sigel chastising someone they once looked up to as well, throwing shots at their fathers for falling short of their expectations.

songs.full_title: Sixteen by Rick Ross (Ft. André 3000)
songs.title: Sixteen

description.plain:
One of many standout tracks off the God Forgives, I Don’t LP featuring an impeccable verse from Andre 3000.

The Bawse also spoke on “Sixteen,” which he said is a “classic.” “Basically it was just when you get some music that you really love or a track that you really love, sometimes sixteen bars is not enough to really express yourself,” said Ross. “We just went to that next level. I think for people to hear Andre do what he did; I'ma let y'all count how many bars he did as well as of course what I did, man. He pulled out the guitar and banjo on this one and he sang a little bit on the end of it. It just broke all the rules of making a standard record.”
Read more here

description.plain:
The debut single of Rick Ross which led to a bidding war and eventually landed him a huge record deal with Def Jam.

It was produced by The Runners and was known for its bombastic production and extremely catchy hook. You could not go ANYWHERE in Miami without hearing this being played on every corner. This track revolutionized the southern hip-hop sound.

songs.full_title: Sorry by Rick Ross (Ft. Chris Brown)
songs.title: Sorry

description.plain:
Rick Ross is gearing up for his eighth studio album, Black Market. “Sorry,” its lead single, hit radio stations on October 6th, 2015 and features Chris Brown.

Chris Brown’s lyrics on this track are predominantly about his past relationship with Karrueche Tran, expressing regret for his actions.

In an interview with TIME Magazine, Ross tells us why “Sorry” is more personal than his usual singles:

I just think it was the right time. When we got in the studio, it was such a powerful record. I think it meant a lot for all of us. You know Chris [Brown], going through his personal thing, it’s so public. His pain, he put it in his words and they became such passionate words. Myself, the things I’ve been faced with over the last few months—you know the type of strife that can cause in any relationship. As well as the producer Scott Storch, I believe this will mark a comeback for Scott Storch in a major way. I think this record is really powerful for a lot of reasons.

On November 12th, 2015 Rick Ross released the official music video to this song. Chris and Rozay both set the tone to the moral of this song by developing a story line of betrayal and disloyalty that ends up in a tragedy.

songs.title: 3 Kings

description.plain:
A Jake One-produced “rags-to-riches” anthem featuring two Hip Hop Kings, Jay Z and Dr. Dre, and an upcoming King, Ricky Rozay, delivering regal raps.

The purely braggadocio “3 Kings” is seen as the centerpiece of God Forgives, I Don’t due to the high-profile nature of the artists involved. It was premiered by Funkmaster Flex on his HOT 97 radio show on July 19, 2012.

description.plain:
The introductory track on Rozay’s highly anticipated and critically acclaimed mixtape Rich Forever.

“Holy Ghost” does a magnificent job at using entendres. Throughout the song, Ross makes references to Christianity. Also, note the church bells in the beat’s background. BING! BING-BING!

songs.full_title: 100 Black Coffins by Rick Ross
songs.title: 100 Black Coffins

description.plain:
Django Unchained is a a Spaghetti Western owing much of its inspiration from Sergio Corbucci’s 1966 film Django. Similar to Franco Nero’s Django, multiple motives compete for primacy in Jamie Foxx’s character. Namely, revenge against his former slave owners and love for his slave wife, Brunhilde. The latter inspires him to embark on a quest to rescue Brunhilde from a dubious and villainous slave owner, Calvin Candie.

Artistdirect called this song “one of the best rap songs of 2012”, praising Ross' wordplay

What the song itself his rap anthem to the wild west and the title refrencing the movie that inspired “Unchained” which is Django" in which the title character of that movie curied a black coffin around where ever he went

Rap Genius asked Ross what the three things he’s got when he’s war ready:

This track marked the end of the long-standing Rozay-Jeezy beef.

description.plain:
Ross and Nas link up for “Triple Beam Dreams"—which was originally featured on Ross' Rich Forever mixtape. It later appeared on Ross' album God Forgives, I Don’t with a slightly different beat.

Check out this post which finds connections between this song and Wu-Tang’s “C.R.E.A.M.”

songs.full_title: Mafia Music by Rick Ross
songs.title: Mafia Music

description.plain:
One of the many stand out tracks and the intro track from his third LP, Deeper Than Rap.

Ross talks of his come up in the rap game, his boisterous cocaine empire, and his large amounts of wealth he has accumulated through drug trafficking and rapping. This was the song that truly began the 50 Cent/Rick Ross beef.

Amidst all of the controversies against Rozay at the time, this song seemed to be a rebirth for him of sorts. Anyone who says “Ross can’t rap” has clearly never heard this song, as Ross goes in to say the least.

songs.title_with_featured: Trap Trap Trap (Ft. Wale & Young Thug)

description.plain:
In the build up towards Ross' latest album Rather You Than Me, released on 17th March 2017, he released a taste of what’s coming with “Trap Trap Trap.”

Both YSL’s Young Thug and MMG’s own Wale join Rozay on this track in which he reminds his listeners and opposition not to try him, while comparing himself to other big names, including rap legend Nas and former American drug kingpin Freeway Rick Ross.

description.plain:
The second track off the album focuses on Ross' past compared to his present while he talks about a lot of sensitive topics like racism, drug dealing and hustling to make it as a minority in America.

Santorini is one of the Cyclades islands in the Aegean Sea. The island is about 200 km (120 mi) southeast of Greece’s mainland and is a popular tourist attraction and location for holidays.

The song samples; Judie Bailey’s Quartet – Colours of My Dream

description.plain:
Rick Ross and Gucci Mane talk about their love of cars and women, while comparing themselves to MC Hammer. MC Hammer is a grammy award winning entertainer who is considered the forefather of pop/rap.

MC Hammer is also known in popular culture for going bankrupt and in essence squandering his fortune on some of the things mentioned in Rick Ross’s song: mansions, strippers, cars, jewelry, and being very generous to his large entourage.

Young Renzel drops a new track off his upcoming album Black Market.

The song in part contains Rozay’s two cents on the Drake/Meek Mill feud, and takes its title from the war-cry of the man who slammed Plies at a concert recently.

songs.full_title: Yella Diamonds by Rick Ross
songs.title: Yella Diamonds

description.plain:
Rick Ross' dope shines like yella diamonds, meaning that he cuts the pure cocaine with baking soda and other substances to increase his profit, turning it yellow in color. He then uses that money to hire hit men to kill people

This song is noteworthy in that while nearly every line ends with “nigga,” the rhyme actually lies in the words before that. Well done, Ross!
